page.title: 01PADIHAM_INTRODUCTION.
page.content: The River Calder splits the town into northern and southern areas and the A671 creates a further division. The name Padiham is derived from the original owners, the sons of{Paddi of {Cockersands Abbey.}1241 is the earliest date for the spelling{ {Padiham.}The town has an area of 4 square kilometres and the population has remained stable at around 10000 for thirty years. The original industries of the town in the 13th century were coal mining and corn milling. From the 18th century until the 1930's 'King Cotton' reigned supreme. Even though the cotton industry has declined, it still plays a minor role in the manufacture of related products such as parachutes, velvet, bandages, survival equipment, handkerchiefs and traditional cotton cloth.
